content.description: The middle route of three routes on the vertical, overhang face left side of the dome. Starts on a natural, cheater stone up past three bolts to an overhangy/bulge. Move through the bulge and over to a slabby face of two more bolts plus anchor.
content.protection: 3/8 in. SS wedge bolts, 5 bolts/chain anchor
content.location: Left side of dome.

content.description: Crux is at the face/bulge near the top. Starts in the hole to the horizontal hand jam/crack and moves right onto the arete. Easy middle to the upper face. Alternate start to the right at the upper level/ledge past a few bolts to join the middle and upper sections. Same difficulty.
Second route from left while belaying in the narrow corridor. Easy, ledges to the face and go onto the upper arete. Second pitch, 5.8 sport option above.
Goes up and left over the small overhang/bulge to easy slab the rest of the way.
content.location: Look for the 45 degree angled overhang/bulge. Route goes up and over this bulge.

content.description: Right goes up and right to get you to the Shady Terrace wall.
content.location: Uphill north of the main wall slabs. Goes right up and over to the grassy ledge.

content.description: 5.8 fun starts low in the hole
content.location: Starts just right around corner down low in the hole

content.description: Harder start to easier climbing up high.
content.location: Start is slightly uphill towards the narrow corridor.

content.description: Two pitch route to the top of Banana Split Dome. 1st pitch- 10b. 2nd pitch- 5.8.
content.protection:
Pitch 1- 11 bolts

Pitch 2- 6 bolts

Chain anchors
content.location: Starts in a small dihedral/crack. Walk directly to the wall from the picnic table on the east side, and find the dihedral a few feet to the left.

content.description: Bolted to chain anchor with lower-offs.
content.location: Farthest most left route on ground level. Starts in the bouldery/cave area

climbs.name: Jacob's Ladder
climbs.fa: Pitch 1- Ben Aguilar- June 2018; Pitch 2- Will Holmquist- May 2020

content.description:
4 Pitches: This is easily linked into 2 pitches. According to the property owner the the 3rd pitch was first sent by Will Holmquist & Lauren Bolin??

Pitch 1: (5.12a) Difficult first few clips to midway easier climbing to a tough finish. Established by Craig Anderson. Can also be used as a first pitch to get to the upper, tall, face climb left of Banana Split crack.

pitch 2: (5.2) Scramble up the mossy slab ( 2 or 3 bolts) to a 2 bolt anchor on the left below the money pitch slab. The anchors on the right are for banana split

Pitch 3: (5.12b) Step right from the anchors to an undercling flake to get onto the face.  12 bolts of excellent quality sustained technical slab climbing.

Pitch 4 :(5.4) Short easy slab climbing to banana split dome summit.
content.location: Face climb on the southern face of Banana Split Dome.

content.description: A mix of smears, crimps and jugs lead to the crux which is about 2/3 the way up at a roof/bulge. Moderate thereafter. Note, the route required nearly all of a 60 m rope. Anything less would not be sufficient to climb and then be lowered. But the 60 m was perfect.
content.location: The base of the route is on the path between the northwest edge of Matterhorn and Split Dome, just as the path begins to ascend over boulders.

content.description: A mix of jugs and scrambling that make for a great warm up.
content.location: The base of the route is on the path between Matterhorn and Banana Split dome, at about the point where the path is narrowest and highest. Like the other routes in this area, a coin size metal placard that reads the grade is located below the first bolt.

content.description: Sustained mid 5.10 climbing. Layback for first few bolts to slab/face the rest of the way.
content.location: Just left of large, detached boulder/flake.

content.description: The right route of the three on the left face. Harder first half to the midway ledge and finish with easier climbing past two more bolts. Chain permadraw halfway for a directional when lowering to clean or toprope.
5.7 easy climb
Start on boulder and step across onto the wall to start.
content.protection: bolts to chain anchor on the slab up high

content.description: The crux is probably the first couple smeary slab moves off the ground which quickly lead to a vegetation filled crack that provides easy hand/foot holds. Continued fun and moderate climbing above.
content.location: This base of this route is on the narrow path between Banana Split Dome and Matterhorn, opposite the north east-ish aspect of Matterhorn. If you were to stand at the base of the route and turn around, you would see the wire-metal ladder that allows TR access to Matterhorn. There are a couple 10b routes to the right/east of this route.

content.description: One move wonder over the overhang. Sharp edge here. Toprope and follower warning.
content.location: Another option for gaining access to the Shady Terrace wall

content.description: Sustained 5.8 through the dihedral up high
Goes up the small overhang at the bottom with a permadraw.
Route is on the obvious face above the east routes of Banana Split dome. Sort of a third pitch. Right side of wall. **Named after the previous property owner's "Camp Sid" directly above the route.
Fun, route up the arete.
content.location: Goes up and right to the arete.

content.description:
Pitch 1: Pull through the thin cracks in the prow at the base of the wall (5.8). Follow incipient cracks (including some horizontals) up the slabby face to a 2-bolt anchor (old SMC hangers).

Pitch 2: Head up the obvious crack.  (Beware poison ivy at the base.)  Where the crack splits (both cracks go right, but one is almost horizontal), follow the more vertical crack up to the top.  The first crux is right where the crack splits; the second crux is still to come.  Both are about 5.8.  There is a 3-bolt anchor at the top.

Variation: Follow the horizontal crack at the split.  (5.6) Lots of rope drag!
content.protection: Standard Rack.  Bolted anchors (with old bolts) that can be backed up with pro.
content.location:
Begin at the base of a small prow with a thin crack.

Rappel the route with two ropes or a 70m.  Bring webbing for the anchors.

The first rappel is at least 35m.

content.description: Start in the dihedral on the right side of the wall.
content.location: Right side of the wall

content.description: Just right of the chimney/flake. Goes straight up over the small bulge.
Starts with a crack and then it's crimps and smears with an occasional rest and jug to the top. A fun, sustained challenge for the 5.10 climber.
content.location: Walk directly to the wall from the picnic table on the east side, and find the small dihedral/crack a few feet to the left - that is Knickerbocker Glory. This route is just to the right/east. Both can be identified by the coin size placard that reads "10b" at the base.

content.description: Sustained face. 70m rope needed.
content.location: Start from inside the detached flake/chimney.

content.description: Straight up the vertical face to the slab above.
content.location: 2nd route to the north from the detached, large flake boulder. Just left of the small overhang about 25 ft up the wall.

content.description: Left most route on the bottom, west side. Sustained, vertical 5.8 jugs all the way to the top.
content.location: Left side, just slightly uphill from ground level routes.

content.description: Slab start with a crack to help leads to a ledge.  Underclings and thoughtful face climbing above.
content.location: This route is left/west most on the south facing aspect of Banana Split dome. There is another 10b to the right of this route, both marked by coin size metal placards at the base.
